ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I think that the professors should have more individual meetings with teams, rather than the workshops (groups of teams). Clinic projects are so diverse, and while there are many common issues faces between them, the workshops didn't provide much value. Individual team meetings would allow teams to talk through the technical aspects of each project, and more specifically discuss the memo's, which were useful, but felt unacknowledged.

Project opportunities were incredibly valuable for hands-on experience and networking. Probably one of the best projects I've been involved with in my three semesters at FES--meaningful and effective. Weekly class was not helpful to me; topics were broad-ranging and disconnected. I would have loved to have had class time be dedicated to project group meetings.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Discussions with our supervisors were very useful and valuable
The opportunity to work with an outside client is (I think obviously) the biggest strength of this class and the primary reason for taking it.
Ability to work in a team setting
I liked the work with clients. I feel that this was good work experience.
The large number of impressive projects to choose from at the beginning of the semester. The client connection that Yale provides.
Working with a client was good professional preparation and a change of pace from other taught classes at F&ES.
Wide variety of interesting, meaningful real-world projects with organizations that I'm interested in working with.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Even though the lectures were useful, it would be great to have further discussions on specific issues that come up regarding our cases, such as the smaller discussions we had within a few groups.

The lecture component to this course was, for the most part, helpful, though I don't think every lecture should be mandatory for people taking the course for the first time (there should be some kind of exemption for people who don't need an "environmental law and policy 101", for example. I also did not get much out of the workshops (which were new this year) and think the class would benefit from scrapping those in favor of more single-group meetings (or if relevant, meetings amongst groups experiencing similar issues or challenges int heir projects). Finally, I think the project bidding should happen before the beginning of the semester (don't think it's too much to ask that students interested in taking the course bid early) so that people can get an even more immediate start on their project as soon as classes begin.
I didn't like the fact there many students were often not in class. I also felt as if some of the lectures and discussions we had were not well organized.

Workshops/team-professor relationship and meetings. Also, the rushed project assignments at the beginning of the semester did not allow for the best team formations. I think students should be able to have some say as to who their teammates are-- I had recruited someone to be on my team, but because of the short timeline for assignments, he was not accepted into the clinic, which was disappointing.
I did not find the structure of the workshops very helpful for our client project. I would suggest re-working those to make it more generative for students.

Class time. I took the course to work on the project. I wanted to spend that time working on the project. The overview of environmental law principles was on-and-off engaging, and overall not helpful to the project or to my interests. Each session was very well taught, and the professors are absolutely experts in their fields, but it was not information that I was seeking.

The lecture component of this course seemed scattered (many different topics, lecturers, etc. with no overarching theme or goals), and the workshops ended up being fairly useless. Although the project itself was great and our group got a lot out of it, we always dreaded going to class. (Although Abbie Dillen was amazing.)

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There was no lab section
I often felt as if the lectures were very disconnected for the projects we were working on.My favorite lecture, and what I felt was the most useful, was the day Josh discussed environmental law.

I did not find most of the lectures that relevant, though they were interesting. Some of the lectures were just scratching the surface of other classes of mine, so were not a good use of my time. Perhaps you could have applications to opt-out of specific lectures if the topic is duplicative of other coursework.
The lecture discussions were interesting. Some of the introductory lectures were quite helpful--especially the background on environmental law for non-law students.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am focused on energy law and finance and therefore much of the work I was doing with the client fit into future projects I may have.
This project fit in very nicely with my work and offered something a little different than my other taught classes.
Capstone, real-world experience with a new-to-me organization.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course because it was a contrast to some of the other courses I was taking and also because it was interesting for me to work with the client,
Exposure to the client and topic we researched.
I was interested in working on a particular client project and this course offered the opportunity to do that. It was ideal.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I am satisfied with the knowledge gained from taking this course
I did not really have any expectations coming into it, but I felt that it was a good learning experience.
Yes, through the project work.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It is great to bounce ideas off each other and collaborate on extensive assignments. Trying to coordinate schedules can get tricky. Effective communication is definitely very important.
it varies. you really need to set the goal with your group members about how you want the project looks like.
I learned from others but it was time consuming to work with everyone's schedue
I had a very goof work group experience. Everyone contributed equally. Sometimes it was difficult to coordinate with everyone's schedules, bit it was mostly positive.
We were able to cover much more research, however, there was less quality control for our final project.
Group work is always a little bit difficult when students have different skill sets and busy schedules. Overall, I think it went pretty well.
I learned as much from my group members as from the project itself. I feel fortunate for having been placed with an excellent team.
Uneven distribution of workload

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: This is a great course to refine consulting skills and the supervisors offer great advise along the way.

Yes, although students thinking about taking this course need to understand that this will be wildly dependent on your particular project and it can be really difficult to anticipate how a certain project will actually play out at the beginning of the semester.
I think the quality of the experience really depends on the client.
Try to lineup a team early on.
Take the course based on the project. Is it something you're specifically interested in? What skills will you gain from working on the project, or what networking links?
Take it early and often!
Make sure you are 100% excited about your project before taking it on! It will consume you...
